channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Global Stocks Tumble Further Amid Doubts About China and Emerging Economies
item.description: The selling accelerated in China’s stock markets, which have slumped in recent weeks despite extraordinary government intervention to prop up prices.
item.dc:creator: NEIL GOUGH
item.media:description: A stock board outside a brokerage in Tokyo on Monday morning. Concerns over China sent markets skidding in Asia.

item.title: ISIS Enshrines a Theology of Rape
item.description: Claiming the Quran’s support, the Islamic State codifies sex slavery in conquered regions of Iraq and Syria and uses the practice as a recruiting tool.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A 12-year-old girl in the Kurdistan region of northern Iraq.

item.title: News Analysis: Future Risks of an Iran Nuclear Deal
item.description: Even some of its strongest backers say they fear that President Obama has oversold some of the deal’s virtues in blocking paths to a nuclear weapon.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry avoided pushing Iran to come clean about past activities.

item.title: ISIS Blows Up Ancient Temple at Syria’s Palmyra Ruins
item.description: Islamic State militants have detonated explosives around the Temple of Baalshamin, one of the most grand and well-preserved structures at the ancient ruins.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: British Embassy Reopens in Iran’s Capital
item.description: The British foreign secretary witnessed the raising of the Union flag over the compound, in a sign of newly thawed relations in the wake of a landmark nuclear deal.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: A Sprawl of Ghost Homes in Aging Tokyo Suburbs
item.description: Some eight million unoccupied homes across Japan are the most visible sign of human retreat in a country where the population is forecast to fall by a third over the next 50 years.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE
item.media:credit: Kentaro Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A tarp covers an abandoned house, at left, that was torn down this year in Yokosuka.

item.title: Guatemala President Balks at Calls for Resignation
item.description: Calls for the resignation of Otto Pérez Molina mounted after prosecutors described him as a leader of a far-reaching scheme to defraud the government of customs revenue in exchange for bribes.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Europe Facing New Uncertainty in Terrorism Fight
item.description: The sheer number of militant suspects combined with a widening field of potential targets have presented European officials with what they concede is a nearly insurmountable surveillance task.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: French soldiers patrolled a train station in Paris on Saturday after Friday's thwarted train attack.

item.title: 9 Opposition Candidates Barred From Venezuela’s December Ballot
item.description: With Venezuela sinking in an economic crisis, raising the prospects of opposition candidates, the government has taken measures to rule several of them ineligible.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Enzo Scarano, a former mayor of San Diego, Venezuela, won a primary for national legislative elections, but the government suspended his right to hold office.

item.title: Sheberghan Journal: Full Bellies Are the Measure of Afghan Influence and Hospitality
item.description: Abdul Rashid Dostum, a former warlord, has retained an edge as a purveyor of old-school Afghan hospitality, as his staff routinely feed hundreds, often thousands, at his palace.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.media:description: Abdul Manan, a cook, in the kitchen of a palace in Sheberghan, Afghanistan. The palace belongs to Vice President Abdul Rashid Dostum.

item.title: Americans Resist Hero Label After Foiling Train Attack
item.description: The three young American men who thwarted an attack on a Paris-bound express train appeared at a news conference on Sunday, brushing aside suggestions that they were heroes.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Explosions Rock U.S. Army Storage Depot Near Tokyo
item.description: No injuries were reported and officials were working to find the cause of the blasts at an Army facility in Sagamihara, Japan, that also caused a fire.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW SIDDONS and MAKIKO INOUE

item.title: Al Qaeda Fighters Try to Seize Yemeni Military Base in Aden
item.description: Fighters with Al Qaeda’s Yemeni affiliate briefly tried to seize control of a military base and the presidential palace before suddenly withdrawing.
item.dc:creator: SAEED AL-BATATI and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: German Town to Add Security After Anti-Refugee Protests
item.description: Protests by right-wing groups against the growing number of refugees in the small town of Heidenau outside Dresden grew violent at times over the weekend.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING

item.title: Clashes Break Out During Protests Over Trash Crisis in Lebanon
item.description: Thousands of protesters streamed into downtown Beirut for a second day on Sunday to demand that the government resign over its inability to remove enormous heaps of garbage.
item.dc:creator: HWAIDA SAAD
item.media:description: Riot police sprayed protesters with water in Beirut as demonstrations entered a second day.

item.title: Myanmar Lawmaker Barred From Re-election on Citizenship Grounds
item.description: Despite more than four years in office, U Shwe Maung, a member of the persecuted Rohingya minority, was told he was not a citizen and was unable to run.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER

item.title: People Sought in Bangkok Bombing May Have Fled Country, Police Say
item.description: Thailand’s chief of police appeared to be trying to lower public expectations that the main person being sought in the explosion at a shrine would be caught anytime soon.
item.dc:creator: POYPITI AMATATHAM and THOMAS FULLER

item.title: North Korea Moves Forces Amid Talks With South
item.description: As negotiators from both sides resumed talks in a border village on Sunday afternoon, Pyongyang was deploying more artillery toward the border, the South said.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Mahmoud Abbas to Resign P.L.O. Leadership Position, Officials Say
item.description: Mr. Abbas would quit as head of the executive committee in a maneuver apparently designed to boost his legitimacy within the organization, committee members said.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: One Year After War, People of Gaza Still Sit Among the Ruins
item.description: Not a single one of the nearly 18,000 homes destroyed or severely damaged in last summer’s war is habitable, despite an Israeli mechanism to approve reconstruction.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN and MAJD AL WAHEIDI
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Few of the thousands of homes destroyed in last summer's war between Israel and Palestinian militants in Gaza, including in Beit Lahiya, have been rebuilt.
